body: Created https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/JENA-2096 for this issue

I don't see any test for compact+delete=true/false for Fuseki.

There are exceptions when running the test suite left over from the previosu PR. There are changes on main to fix some of them 
a4346e6493 : `jena-fuseki-main/testing/FusekiEmbedded/tdb2-config.ttl` and 927b137bcd test `compact_01`.
(so please rebase).

`TestConfigFile.serverTDB2` is still throwing an exception. The compact there can simply be removed and a test for compact in Fuseki provided separately, which run compact both with and without delete=true and tests the Fuseki disk state. (All in one test means only one new database created.) 

The compact/delete-true case can be skipped for Windows.

The problem is that the tests have a memory TDB2 database and that does not provide compact. Compact is a disk-based operation.
@afs whoops. seems that I missed that test. I'll add it now.
@afs I've added a test for fuseki main
@dependabot rebase

https://github.com/apache/jena/pull/988#issuecomment-828611307

@afs I believe that I've also fixed the exception thrown by the fuseki main tests.
Rebased (accidentally rebased against `master` :rofl: saved by `git reflog` :pray: )
Thanks for checking - I found it difficult to be sure because of the browser caching.

@afs rebased, and squashed the commits (so instead of 96 commits, we have a single one now :sweat_smile: ).

I'll look into the Maven build next. I guess I can just make `jena-fuseki2` webapp to build the `war` and copy all the files produced by `jena-fuseki-ui` inside the generated `war`. That should — in theory — replace the existing Backbone.js app, and re-build it whenever `jena-fuseki-ui` Vue.js app is modified.

@afs in my last commit I tried to modify the Jetty application start up in `FusekiCmd` to load the resources from a `target/webapp` folder that contains the original `jena-fuseki-webapp` files, and also the `jena-fuseki-ui` Vue.js app files copied. See the pom.xml change for more.

I don't understand completely how Jena & Fuseki & Jetty work, so there might be better ways to structure how we get the files from `jena-fuseki-ui` into `jena-fuseki-webapp` (which from what I understood, goes into `jena-fuseki-war` later on)
Small point: could the commit message say something like "JENA-2107: Substitute in RDF-star triple pattern"

Looks good - builds, which is the main thing.

@Claudenw : Is there a JIRA for this?

For each version, there is a URL for all tickets labeled as fixed for a release for people who want details of all changes.
For next release: https://s.apache.org/jena-4.1.0-jira (it works per and post release state)

If you want it on that list, could you please add a JIRA and ref the PR  or main commit?
Argh, was going to rebase to quickly update deps, but for the third time in this PR I've rebased onto `master` instead of `main` :cry:

Was going to use `reflog` to undo the mess I did here, but looking at the list of things I still need to implement

- [ ] figure out how to get Fuseki and the Maven build with the new UI
- [ ] write unit / e2e tests
- [ ] update dependencies (JS libs are released quite rapidly, since the PR was created I updated it a few times, but today I was going to try some major updates)

Soon would also have to

- [ ] update to Vue3 and TS
- [ ] keep updating our JS libs

I think I'd be the only dev maintaining it, and moving it forward would need a few hours month, which I have for the next 1-2 years. But would still be better to have `busFactor > 1`. I think for now we can keep using the old Backbone.js app. Fix any JS bugs if necessary, and update the JS libs manually when/if necessary.

2100 of the new files are the ShEx community test suite.

This is available under the W3C Software License (as is SPARQL).
Added a fix for JENA-2120 to this PR because it builds on changes made for the ShEx test suite that also address JENA-2118.
test message to check linkage with JIRA, ignore me please :)
Looks like these dependencies are up-to-date now, so this is no longer needed.

If the PR is of the format "JENA-nnnn: text" there will be a link in JIRA.

JENA must be uppercase.

Also - it helps if the important commits are of the form "JENA-2029:...." so that looking at the git history, the programmer can see 
where substantive changes happened and why.

This isn't about

https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/JENA-2029

Too many errors.  I am closing this and will create a new branch and pull request.  Sorry for the inconvenience

Hi @Aklakan -- looks good.

Would it be possible to test(s) to `TestVarRename` for this?

The `TestVarRename.query_rename_*` provide query to algebra testing.
Hi Andy, I added a test case using a query for which the test fails without the PR.
Thanks for the test case.
It's too much to review, but I hope it's designed that way that the HTTP layer can be decoupled from the RDF machinery and replaced with something else, like JAX-RS.
@namedgraph I'm not totally sure what you mean-- wouldn't JAX-RS make more sense for server-side usage? What's needed here is really a low-level HTTP client, it seems to me...
WIP apache/jena-site#64 ; preview at:  https://jena.staged.apache.org/documentation/sparql-apis/

@ajs6f we've been through this on the mailing list :) But JAX-RS is not only server but also client: https://docs.oracle.com/javaee/7/api/javax/ws/rs/client/package-summary.html

Not sure why it has to be "really low-level", I think my problem with the Jena API is that low-level stuff like timeouts get mixed together with entity-level stuff such as reading results. And that Jena's API is just a special RDF-based case in a more general HTTP API framework (such as JAX-RS).

Example of what I mean, Jena's API:

```
ResultSet resulrs = qExec.execSelect();
```
JAX-RS:
```
ResultSet resulrs = response.readEntity(ResultSet.class);
```
My natural instinct is to generalize and go for the second example, which we've done in [Core](https://github.com/AtomGraph/Core).

But if you need low-level control, Jersey client has a [connector for the Apache HTTP client](https://eclipse-ee4j.github.io/jersey.github.io/apidocs/latest/jersey/org/glassfish/jersey/apache/connector/ApacheConnectorProvider.html) which allows you to provide all the native configuration.
Jena spatial functions are provided by [geosparql module](https://jena.apache.org/documentation/geosparql/#property-functions)

This work has been signaled for months. The code has been available for months.

It is not a change to the Jena APIs. That has been said repeatedly.
@dependabot close
@dependabot recreate
Looks like org.apache:apache is up-to-date now, so this is no longer needed.
@acoburn Is this part of the Titanium API stable for javax, non-jakarta usage?

I took this branch and made a few minor modifications (to see if it would work with JakartaEE 8). I was able to get it to compile and the initialization steps in LangJSONLD11.Sys worked correctly. This was with Titanium 0.8.6 (the last version to support JakartaEE8) and org.glassfish:jakarta.json version 1.1.6

The challenge is that the Titanium API has changed in subtle ways between 0.8.6 and 1.x. For example, in both versions, the `com.apicatalog.jsonld.JsonLd.toRdf(com.apicatalog.jsonld.document.Document)` method returns a `ToRdfApi` object. But in 0.8.6, that class is located in the `com.apicatalog.jsonld.api.impl` package, and in 1.1.0, that class is in the `com.apicatalog.jsonld.api` package.

So when using this with a JakartaEE 8 platform, I end up with this error: 

```
java.lang.NoSuchMethodError: 'com.apicatalog.jsonld.api.ToRdfApi com.apicatalog.jsonld.JsonLd.toRdf(com.apicatalog.jsonld.document.Document)
```

One approach would be to only support JakartaEE 9 with this code. That might be a fine first step.

The way I was approaching this involved using two separate packages: `jena-jsonld` and `jena-jsonld-jee8` in which the first one used the JakartaEE 9 packages and Titanium version 1.1.0. The second package used the JakartaEE 8 packages and the earlier version of Titanium. Then the ServiceLoader did all the work in terms of bringing in the right version (provided that the user of the library included the correct dependency)
One thing to note is that this code (as currently written) continues to work in JakartaEE 8 environments, provided one doesn't use `Lang.JSONLD11` in the parser.

I don't understand the point about `Lang.JSONLD11` - that constant definition does not depend on Titanium.

Definition of Lang constants is not ("should not be") tied to implementation.

We can tune the guards so that the provided code only does anything if Titanium 1.1 is present, and not 0.8.6.
That is, test for `com.apicatalog.jsonld.api.impl.JsonLD`.

A separate module can add Titanium 0.8.6 (which can be done with the released Jena - that's what you do currently I presume?)(there is a example for adding a language).

It would be nice to remove the print-parse.

> I don't understand the point about Lang.JSONLD11 - that constant definition does not depend on Titanium.

Indeed, I meant `riot.lang.LangJSONLD11`

> A separate module can add Titanium 0.8.6

Yes, that is what I do currently
What is a good test class for the looking for Titanium 1.1.0 and not 0.8.6?

How about `com.apicatalog.jsonld.JsonLdVersion`?

That class was renamed from `com.apicatalog.jsonld.lang.Version` in the 0.8.6 -> 1.0.0 transition.

Fixup changes:

* Test class for Titanium changed to `com.apicatalog.jsonld.JsonLdVersion`
* Always register constant `Lang.JSONLD11` (not in `LangJSONLD11`) so the reader class does not have to.

If this Quarkus statement about JakartaEE9 is still current:

https://developers.redhat.com/blog/2020/09/11/quarkus-and-jakarta-ee-together-or-not

things are not hopeful.

w.r.t statement about Quarkus and JakartaEE, I think that might be a little dated. Quarkus makes extensive use of MicroProfile (as mentioned in that post), and MicroProfile is very much moving towards using [JakartaEE 9](https://github.com/eclipse/microprofile/issues/223). Once MP makes the jump to JakartaEE 9+, I would suspect that Quarkus will follow suit.

From a security POV, we'd ideally like to offer pluggable context loading with a simple contract, e.g. some folks may want to load from a secure immutable store. That scenario was much-discussed during 1.1 WG. Does Titanium already offer something like that?

@ajs6f Try asking on JENA-1948 which is more likely to get attention.

(Judging by class names, the answer is "yes" - the question is "how?")
This work is now sufficiently complete to be put into the codebase.

> haven't figured out how to preload/cache contexts but that looks important for both performance and privacy/security.

In Titanium, one would write something like this:

```java
JsonLd.toRdf(...).loader(myCustomLoader).get();
```

There is a built-in document loader with certain caching properties; the code above allows a user to override that default with their own implementation of the `DocumentLoader` [interface](https://javadoc.io/doc/com.apicatalog/titanium-json-ld/latest/com/apicatalog/jsonld/loader/DocumentLoader.html).

If you're able to use your own DocumentLoader, then you have complete control over what is loaded and how that resolution is performed. That structure also allows you to selectively accept/reject certain context documents based on allow/deny lists. This gets to @ajs6f's [comment](https://github.com/apache/jena/pull/1045#issuecomment-895585968) about using an immutable store. In my own code, I have found this to be really useful, but also very specific to the particular use case.

@acoburn -- thanks.

It's a JSON-LD issues that contexts are like a data version of tracking cookies and pixels, and not specifically about Titanium. 

Anyway, if this PR looks good, we can go with the state here.

This is further along than I hoped for and more complete than the basic first PR. We may be able to smooth the legal issues if we have time. It's 425K more in the downloads.

This PR looks good in its present form.

Eventually, it will be nice to have support for doing something like this:

```java
RDFParser.create().source(...).lang(JSONLD11).context(jsonldReadContext).parse(...);
```
where that `context` contains some mechanism to adjust how the JSON-LD `@context` resolution happens in Titanium (e.g. document loader). For instance, since that Jena `Context` object is already sent to the LangJSONLD11::read method, it might be possible to use that object to customize how the Titanium parsing proceeds.
From an API POV, I'd distinguish `.context(jsonldReadContext)` from `.contextLoader(jsonldReadContextLoader)`.

The way I think this would be done is via:

```java
public RDFParserBuilder set(Symbol symbol, Object value)
```
```java
RDFParser.create().source(...).lang(JSONLD11).set(symJsonldContext, jsonldReadContext).parse(...);
```

This style is done on newer WIP:
https://github.com/apache/jena/blob/061a71346ea0edc50a9ebd816fc7394869a9d893/jena-arq/src/main/java/org/apache/jena/sparql/exec/QueryExecDatasetBuilder.java#L115

where we have `set` operations for the context as well as `context` which is replacement.
```java
    public QueryExecDatasetBuilder set(Symbol symbol, Object value)

    public QueryExecDatasetBuilder set(Symbol symbol, boolean value)

    public QueryExecDatasetBuilder context(Context context)
```
`RDFParser` only has the last form.
(I am trying to support this style by some simple code pattern but not had time; inheritance is used for something else in other cases.)

This avoids `RDFParserBuilder` having an API dependency specially for JSON-LD which I think is important.
Then we can distinguish with two different symbols, one for context and one for context loader, yes?

> two different symbols, one for context and one for context loader,

Yes.

The (RIOT) context is a map of symbols (best named with URIs for global uniqueness) to Objects.

So (JSON-LD) context setup and the (Titanium) context loader can be (RIOT) context entries.

Back to draft because this is not for the 4.2.0 release. There are unrelated new features in 4.2.0 so don't want to hinder getting those out to users.

It can go in quite soon after 4.2.0 to give it the most time to settle in.

Hi @ebremer,

What's the long term situation here? Is the work in Solid a different namespace? Is it compatible with this (up to 2016) vocabulary?
Maybe the class name should be `WebAccessControl`.

The name space is the same as what is used in Solid: https://solid.github.io/web-access-control-spec/
The long term goal is to track those newer changes introduced by the Solid project.  I called the class "ACL" as it was short and convenient and followed their prefix abbreviation ACL.

This is looking like good timing. While I, personally, think using SERVICE for extensions for stored procedures isn't perfect, it does stay within standard syntax which is valued by users and has some take-up.

Thanks for following existing design patterns (even if they are, with hindsight a bit overly complex in places!).

Starting with design review:

_Deferred start_

Delayed initialization can handled orthogonally. See
`IteratorDelayedInitialization` for example. `Supplier` is coping with an uncommon case
that I think can be done within an implementation anyway.

_Location_

> Probably it is indeed better to move the code from QueryIterService to Service - but add the 'Binding' argument to the function in Service

Possible, though I don't think it make much difference either way.  Leave it in `QueryIterService` for now?

_Default_

I'd like to handle the default case (in the PR, no factory found) as a regular `ServiceExecutorFactory` added from `ARQ.init` rather than code here. It is nice to have a "really no SERVICE support" done by clearing the registry even if we keep the old context approach.

The code will need to handle "no factory found" as `QueryExecException` or a join-identity
query iterator depending on `SILENT`.

_Substituted vs original op_

This isn't so easy to treat as separate.

* A dispatch may be `SERVICE ?service` with `?service` already bound but the
registration is to `<someURI>`.

* This code is in `nextStage` so iteration is happening further out. If the implementation wants bottom-up only, might have to have a different optimizer - i.e. needs to take a wider view. It can still do a single execution and keep that internally (`QueryIterator.close` will be called for clear-up).

I don't think that is common so the API can focus on the usual case because the other can still be done as long as the original is available.

How about providing both in the factory call so the implementation is informed?

With those points:

```java
public interface ServiceExecutorFactory {
    QueryIterator createExecutor(OpService op, OpService original, Binding binding, ExecutionContext context);
}
```

The switch to `ExecutionContext` is a good idea.

_Timing_

We are close to the 4.2.0 release point. As an extension to advertise, we should take the time to get it right. A whole cycle (3-4 months) is a bit long so my suggestion is include in 4.2.0 with the understanding that it is "Experimental - work-in-progress - subject to refinement".

Thanks for the updates.

How about WebACL? It's just "ACL" just feels a bit weak because this is specific to web operations. 
(It should be "WAC" from the wiki ... wonder why that hasn't taken off!)

Vocabularies don't have to be in jena itself - it does not convey any magic to them - but this is a W3C work. If Solid add something, presumably it will go in a different namespace or get community agreement.
WAC would fine with me.  Keeps it short and less ambiguous.  What say you?
OK
Done.
Suggested changes made to https://github.com/afs/jena/tree/service (including moving tests to jena-integration as per an old comment). The branch is based off the PR commits.
added FOAF this morning

Hi - a few process things:

* please could you changes to different vocabularies in different PRs especially changes like the capitalization alterations.
* The commits reflect your development - when in the codebase, log messages are more about the substantive changes (think about what someone wants to read in 2-5 years time!). If the intermediate could be squashed that would be great.

Jena already has FOAF.java (in org.apache.jena.sparql.vocabulary because i tis used in standard W3C test cases).
It was generated using schemagen from the FOAF schema document itself. schema also includes the items rdfs:comment as its javadoc.
Will do.

`ServiceExecutor` works for me. Maybe `ServiceExecution` c.f. `QueryExecution`. Executor is, to me, then thing that does work, may called several times, not the outcome of the work.

Both are better than `Supplier` which does not say anything about calling `get()` multiple times (same object? new object each time?) . Jena has `Creator` for that role.

I'll make the changes - due to timing, 4.2.0 needs to get out soon and I have a window of time to do the release; we can refine this as necessary
Thanks, this is a nice improvement
Included in PR #1070 .
Just a note that this is very exciting. I have been using the Thrift binding with Jena for some time, and this option will be nice.
@acoburn  Interesting to hear!
@kinow Thank you very much for all the comments. I hope I've addressed them.
Adding other small cleanups.

Having the default graph as referenced `Model` in the returned `Resource`s would allow to add statements about the named graphs using the Resources methods, which feels right. But I don't have an overview about possible side effects, e.g. in case if there is no statement about the resource in the default graph yet.
Wouldn't [`ServletContextListener`](https://javaee.github.io/javaee-spec/javadocs/javax/servlet/ServletContextListener.html) work here?

No.

That's more like JenaSystem initialization which Jena already has.

1. ServletContextListener does not hook into the Fuseki build cycle in a way that allows modules to enhance a server. 
3. ServletContextListener is called in the wrong direction - Fuseki modules call out.
2. Fuseki main does not have a deployment descriptor; it's not a Java "web application" in the complete sense.
Why isn't Fuseki a Java webapp?

Why should it be? It does not help - see list above. All you get is an "have started" event. So what?

This PR is included in the follow-up PR #1086.

Since we're generalising this mechanism a couple of things jump out to me:

- Do we want to force initialisers of the same level to run in a predictable order likely by breaking the comparison tie with a lexical comparison on class name.  That way if folks are using this mechanism and (un)intentionally use the same level as a system module the order of operations remains predictable.  This seems particularly important since this PR increases the range of levels considered to be Jena system so pre-existing initialisers might get bitten by this.
- A bare `sl.forEach()` without any exception handling is going to throw an exception should it encounter an unloadable class likely leading to a) a JVM exit with nasty stack trace or b) silently carrying on in a partially initialised state without any obvious indication to the user depending on how and when initialisation is getting called.  Some explicit error handling and bail out may be warranted.

I realise both of these are pre-existing issues of the old code but since you're revisiting the code might be worth addressing?

It would be a good idea to handle bad initialization and log.

Initializers are supposed permanent extensions, not ad hoc extra functionality. It is not alt-OSGi! So better reporting but because there is no isolation guarantees, the system has to be considered unstable.

The debug helps with the overlap issue.

We could now have a reserved "jena service loader" then a separate "application service loader" if the interface names are different.

I am confused by talking about `sl.forEach()` - there is only one such call `sl.forEach(this::add)`and it is adding an existing object to a registry. It is not calling the loaded service in any way..

@rvesse -- what had you in mind here?

Java has static imports:
```
import org.apache.jena.system.RDFStar.*;
```
and then the function name is used without class qualification: `encodeRDFStar`. 

Eclipse, and I expect other IDEs, provide code suggestions to use this shorter form.

To me, `encodeAsRDF` is not better because it does not include "RDFStar".

The full name `encodeRDFStarAsRDF` is not pretty with the RDF repetition and there is the "InPlace" variant.

`decodeRDFStar` could be better but it does at least pair with "encode" and include "RDFStar".

The reification to RDF Star quoted triples makes an assumption that there is only one S-P-O refication so it is not a general reification to RDFStar process.

`sl.forEach()` is the place where the created `ServiceLoader`'s iterator is enumerated. `ServiceLoader` loads and instantiates implementations lazily from the relevant `META-INF/services/<interface>` file(s) on the class path.

So when you call `forEach()` it's trying to go through the iterator and at that point several classes of failures are possible and would throw an exception:

- A class does not exist
- A class does not actually implement the required interface
- A class exists but has some static initialisation logic in its definition that fails

Any of these errors would cause the `sl.forEach()` call to throw an exception

i.e. all these errors can happen prior to ever actually trying to use the loaded class

depends on how you write it. if you write it as `RDFStar.encodeAsRDF`, i think it's clear that you have an RDFStar object and you're encoding it as RDF.

Great - my main use case is the Async parser itself for the xloader. This requires all parser events to flow, not just triples or quads. It uses the StreamRDF form so isn't pull-parser.

About prefixes:

Internal class `EltStreamRDF` transfers one parser event (triple or quad or prefix or base or exception).

The main function `AsyncParser.asyncParse(String filesOrURL, StreamRDF output)` has a `StreamRDF` passes exactly the same as synchronous parsing to `output`.

To be used as a pull parser, using `Iterator<T>` - `asyncParseTriples` etc - and like Piped*, there has to be a specific `T`. As replacement for the existing functionality, `Iterator<Triple>`, there isn't the chance to see prefixes. But `AsyncParser.asyncParse(..., StreamRDF)` is the main operation.
Thanks for the thoughts on prefixes and more detail on how everything is fitting together 👍
